title: Epic: Undo/Redo & Command Pattern â€” Reversible actions for 3D block placement
description:
## Problem

3D building is inherently error-prone. Depth perception is harder than 2D â€” players WILL misplace blocks inside dense structures where the wrong block is buried behind walls. Without undo, the only recourse is right-clicking to hunt for and delete the mistake, which may be invisible without cutaway mode.

Every successful building game (Minecraft, Cities Skylines, The Sims, Factorio) has undo or trivial deletion. In a game where structures are complex and enclosed, undo is the difference between "fun to build" and "rage quit."

## What Needs Design

### Command Pattern Architecture
- Every mutating action becomes a Command object with execute() and undo()
- Command types needed:
  - PlaceBlockCommand(definition, origin, rotation) â†’ stores block_id for undo
  - RemoveBlockCommand(block_id) â†’ stores full block state for redo
  - RotateBlockCommand (if rotation becomes post-placement)
  - ExcavateCommand(grid_pos) â†’ stores strata type for undo
  - FillAreaCommand(definition, cells) â†’ stores all placed block_ids
  - PasteCommand(blueprint, origin) â†’ stores all placed block_ids
  - (Future) MoveBlockCommand, ChangePanelCommand, etc.
- Command stack with configurable max depth (100? 500?)
- Redo stack (cleared on new action, standard behavior)

### Multi-Block Undo
- Area fill places 25 blocks â€” undo should reverse ALL 25 in one step
- Corridor drag-to-build places N segments â€” undo reverses entire path
- Need concept of "compound commands" that group sub-commands

### Structural Integrity on Undo
- Removing a block via undo might leave blocks above unsupported
- Options: (a) undo always succeeds, structural check is advisory, (b) undo refuses if it would create structural violation, (c) undo cascades â€” removes the undone block AND anything it was supporting
- This is a design decision with gameplay implications

### UX
- Ctrl+Z / Ctrl+Shift+Z (standard keybinds)
- Visual feedback: briefly highlight what was undone/redone
- Undo history panel? (show last N actions, click to undo to that point)
- How many undos to support? (Memory vs. convenience)

### Interaction with Save/Load
- Does saving clear the undo stack?
- Does loading restore an undo stack?
- Should undo history be part of the save file?

### Interaction with Game Simulation
- In sandbox/build mode (Phase 0): undo is straightforward, no simulation running
- In live game (Milestone 6+): undoing a block placement while simulation is ticking â€” does time rewind? Or just geometry reverts? (Probably just geometry â€” you can't un-simulate agent behavior)

## Open Questions
1. Should undo be limited to building actions, or also cover camera movements, UI state?
2. Maximum undo depth â€” memory implications for 500 undos of 25-block fill operations?
3. Should undo work across save/load boundaries?
4. How does undo interact with multiplayer (if ever)?
5. Should there be a "revert to last save" as a nuclear undo option?
6. Can compound commands be partially undone? (Undo 3 of the 25 blocks in a fill?)

## Dependencies
- Should be designed before multi-block operations (area fill, paste)
- Command pattern affects how placement code is structured â€” worth implementing early
- Current placement in sandbox_main.gd is direct mutation, would need refactoring

## Implementation Sketch
```gdscript
class_name Command extends RefCounted
func execute() -> bool: return false  # override
func undo() -> bool: return false     # override
func description() -> String: return "" # for UI

class_name CommandStack extends Node
var undo_stack: Array[Command] = []
var redo_stack: Array[Command] = []
const MAX_UNDO = 200

func do(cmd: Command) -> bool:
    if cmd.execute():
        undo_stack.append(cmd)
        redo_stack.clear()
        if undo_stack.size() > MAX_UNDO:
            undo_stack.pop_front()
        return true
    return false
```

description:
## Problem

Currently placement is one block at a time. A player building a 100-floor arcology needs to lay out hundreds of identical residential floors, long corridor runs, repeated infrastructure patterns. Without bulk operations, building at scale is so tedious that players won't reach the interesting simulation parts â€” they'll burn out on manual block-by-block placement.

Every successful building game solves this: Minecraft has fill commands and WorldEdit, Cities Skylines has zoning brushes, Factorio has blueprints and copy/paste, The Sims has room duplication.

## What Needs Design

### Area Fill
- Select block type â†’ drag a 3D box (start corner to end corner) â†’ fill entire volume
- 2D variant: drag a 2D rectangle on a single floor â†’ fill that floor area
- Works with any block type, respects rotation
- Preview shows ghost of entire fill before confirming
- Validation: all cells must be buildable, show count of blocks to be placed
- Consider: should fill skip occupied cells (fill around existing blocks) or require empty volume?

### Region Delete
- Select a 3D box â†’ delete all blocks within it
- Or: "delete floor" â€” remove all blocks at a given Y level
- Structural integrity warning: "Deleting these blocks will leave 47 blocks unsupported. Proceed?"
- Cascading delete option: "Delete these AND everything they support"
- Preview: highlight blocks that will be deleted in red before confirming

### Copy/Paste
- Select region (3D box) â†’ copy to clipboard
- Paste at new location with ghost preview
- Rotation of pasted region (0/90/180/270)
- Mirror option (flip east-west or north-south)
- Paste respects validation â€” shows which blocks can/can't place in new location
- What gets copied? Block types + rotations + relative positions. NOT simulation state.

### Blueprints
- Save a copied region as a named blueprint
- Blueprint library accessible from build menu
- Pre-built blueprints: "standard residential floor", "elevator core", "corridor ring"
- Player-created blueprints saved with game
- Share blueprints between save files? Export/import?

### Repeat/Pattern Tools
- "Repeat upward" â€” copy current floor and stack N times above
- "Repeat along axis" â€” copy a section and repeat it along X or Z
- This is the killer feature for arcology-scale building: design one floor, repeat it 50 times

### Interaction with Undo
- Area fill (25 blocks) â†’ Ctrl+Z should undo ALL 25 as one operation
- Compound command pattern (see Undo/Redo epic)
- Same for region delete: undoing a delete restores all removed blocks

### Interaction with Structural Integrity
- Pasting a section in mid-air â€” reject if no support, or allow with warning?
- Area fill at Y=5 with nothing below â€” require column support first?
- Should there be a "scaffolding" mode that temporarily ignores structural rules?

### Selection as Foundation
- All multi-block operations require a selection system first
- Box selection: click-drag to define 3D region
- How to define a 3D box with a 2D mouse? Options:
  - Click two corners (one for XZ, one for Y)
  - Click floor plane for XZ, then scroll/drag for Y height
  - Click start corner, drag to end corner on same floor, then Shift+scroll to extend vertically
- Selection ticket exists (arcology-d4g) but is P2 â€” should this be elevated?

## Open Questions
1. What's the minimum viable version? (Probably: area fill on one floor + undo)
2. Should blueprints include block TYPE info only, or also panel/material preferences?
3. How do multi-cell blocks interact with area fill? (A 3x1x1 beam doesn't tile neatly into a 5x5 area)
4. Should there be a "stamp" mode? (Click repeatedly to paste blueprint at cursor)
5. Cost implications â€” filling 100 blocks at once should cost 100x, shown before confirming
6. Performance â€” placing 1000 blocks in one operation needs to be batched, not 1000 individual place_block calls
7. Should blueprints be block-type-agnostic? ("Fill this area with whatever block I have selected")

## Dependencies
- Selection system (arcology-d4g) is a prerequisite for all of this
- Undo/Redo command pattern (arcology-0ru) needed for reversible bulk operations
- Structural integrity validation needs batch mode (check entire operation, not per-block)
- Economy system â€” bulk operations need bulk cost calculation
- Ghost preview system needs to handle hundreds of preview blocks without killing FPS

## Scale Reference
- 1 floor of a modest building: 10x10 = 100 blocks
- 20-floor building: 2,000 blocks placed manually = painful
- 20-floor building with repeat: 100 blocks designed + 19 repeats = manageable
- Full arcology (50x50x60): 150,000 blocks â€” IMPOSSIBLE without bulk tools

# Phase 3: 3D Block Rendering System

**Goal:** Render blocks as 3D meshes with proper materials and LOD.

**Depends on:** Phase 1 (arcology-wb0)

## Components

### BlockRenderer3D
- Creates MeshInstance3D per block
- Positions at grid coordinates
- Applies correct rotation
- Manages materials (selection, damage, overlay states)

### Block Mesh Structure
```gdscript
BlockVisuals {
    exterior_mesh: Mesh      # Outer shell
    interior_mesh: Mesh      # For cutaway view
    collision_mesh: Mesh     # Simplified
    lod_meshes: [Mesh]       # LOD0-LOD3
    material: ShaderMaterial
}
```

### LOD System
| Distance | LOD | Detail |
|----------|-----|--------|
| 0-50m | LOD0 | Full + interior |
| 50-150m | LOD1 | Simplified exterior |
| 150-400m | LOD2 | Silhouette |
| 400m+ | LOD3 | Merged chunks |

### Chunk System
- 8x8x8 cube chunks
- Merge static geometry per chunk
- Rebuild only changed chunks
- Frustum cull entire chunks

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Blocks render as 3D meshes
- [ ] Selection highlight works
- [ ] LOD transitions smooth
- [ ] 10,000 blocks at 60 FPS

title: Epic: Phase 0 Sandbox Completeness Audit â€” Track what's implemented vs. 3D refactor vision
description: Assess the Phase 0 sandbox (scenes/phase0_sandbox.tscn, src/phase0/) against the 3D refactor vision in arcology-3d-refactor.md. The sandbox is estimated at 65-75% complete. Strong areas: cell/grid system, camera, placement, input, environment, scenario. Weak areas: no LOD, no chunk system, no visibility modes (cutaway/x-ray/isolate), no panel system, no interior rendering, no drag-to-build corridors. Each missing feature gets a ticket tracking the gap.

title: DONE: Cell system & grid architecture â€” 6m cubes, Vector3i coordinates, face directions (100%)
description: ASSESSMENT: Fully implemented. grid_utils.gd has CELL_SIZE=6.0, grid_to_world, world_to_grid, grid_to_world_center. face.gd has all 6 face directions with normals and adjacency offsets. Y-up coordinate system (X=east, Y=up, Z=north). Multi-cell block occupancy working. No gaps.

title: GAP: Chunk system not implemented â€” no geometry merging, high draw calls (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 3.5) defines an 8x8x8 cell chunk system for rendering optimization. Currently each block is a separate MeshInstance3D = 1 draw call per block. Performance degrades around 5000+ blocks. Chunks would: merge static opaque geometry into single draw calls, separate mesh layers (opaque/transparent/interior/dynamic), rebuild only changed chunks, enable frustum culling. Note: existing epic arcology-3yo covers 3D Block Rendering System. This is a critical blocker for scale.

title: GAP: LOD system not implemented â€” all blocks render at full detail always (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 3.4) defines 4 LOD levels: LOD0 (0-50m, full detail + interior), LOD1 (50-150m, simplified exterior), LOD2 (150-400m, silhouette), LOD3 (400m+, merged impostors). Currently all blocks render at full detail regardless of distance, creating a performance cliff for large builds. Note: existing ticket arcology-m0v covers LOD. This pairs with the chunk system for scale.

title: GAP: Panel auto-generation not implemented â€” no exterior face materials (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Sections 3.3, 3.6) defines auto-generated panels on cube faces touching exterior/void. Each block should have panel_slots (top/bottom/north/south/east/west) with material types: solid concrete, glass, metal, solar, garden, force field. Each material has distinct mesh style and shader properties. Currently all blocks are plain colored BoxMesh with no face differentiation. This is important for visual identity and building readability.

title: GAP: Interior mesh system not implemented â€” no furniture/fixtures visible in cutaway (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 3.3) defines dual mesh per block: exterior_mesh (outer shell) + interior_mesh (furniture/fixtures for cutaway view). Currently blocks have only a single BoxMesh. Interior meshes are what make cutaway mode meaningful â€” without them, cutting away the exterior just shows empty space. Depends on cutaway mode implementation.

title: GAP: Drag-to-build corridors not implemented â€” stubbed but non-functional (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 6.6) defines drag-to-build for corridors: click start, drag to end, preview shows path with auto-corners and auto-junctions, release to build entire path. Manhattan routing only (no diagonals), same Y level. Code is stubbed in sandbox_main.gd but doesn't actually function. This is a major UX convenience for building connected walkways.

title: GAP: Advanced placement validation missing â€” no cantilever limits, prerequisites, warnings (40%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 6.5) defines full placement validation: structural support (done), cantilever limits based on gravity (not done â€” see scenario-config.md), prerequisite checking (not done), yellow warning states for 'valid but risky' (not done â€” only green/red). Missing warnings: 'will block light to floors below', 'corridor dead-ends here', 'far from utilities'. Basic BFS support detection works but doesn't respect cantilever distance.

title: GAP: View Cube widget not implemented (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 4.4) defines a corner View Cube widget: click face to snap to ortho view, click edge for 45-degree view, click corner for isometric, drag to free rotate. Currently camera views are only accessible via keyboard shortcuts. Note: existing ticket arcology-ha9 covers this. Low priority for Phase 0 but nice for UX.

title: GAP: Performance optimization minimal â€” no frustum culling, no occlusion culling, no instancing (10%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 8) targets 60fps at 10k-50k blocks. Currently smooth camera works and shadows are enabled (basic optimization), far plane set to 3000m. But: no frustum culling (all chunks render), no occlusion culling (behind-geometry chunks render), no GPU instancing (repeated elements not batched), no deferred rendering, no async streaming. Performance cliff at ~5000 blocks. Pairs with chunk and LOD systems.

title: GAP: PBR materials not implemented â€” basic StandardMaterial3D only (0%)
description: The 3D refactor spec (Section 3.2) targets 'stylized realism with PBR materials'. Currently using basic StandardMaterial3D with flat color and emission. Missing: metallic/roughness variation, subsurface scattering (for garden panels), normal maps, material variation by block type. Low priority for Phase 0 â€” functional but not visually polished.

title: GAP: Controller support not implemented (0%)

title: Epic: Building Experience - Make Block Placement Feel Like Minecraft/Lego
description:
# Epic: Building Experience

**Priority:** P0 - NOTHING ELSE MATTERS UNTIL THIS WORKS

The 3D spike proves the tech works but the building experience is unusable. Players need to feel like they're playing Minecraft or snapping Lego - instant, obvious, satisfying.

## Problems
1. Terrain is a flat gray plane - no grid, doesn't look like ground
2. Block placement is single-click only - can't rapid-build
3. No visual feedback on which face you're targeting
4. No floor/level indicator
5. No help menu
6. No undo
7. No block selection/info

## Success Criteria
- [ ] New player can build a 5-story building in under 2 minutes
- [ ] Grid is immediately visible on terrain
- [ ] Terrain looks like actual ground
- [ ] Can hold-click to rapid-place blocks
- [ ] Can drag to draw corridors
- [ ] Clear feedback on which face is targeted
- [ ] Always know what floor you're on
- [ ] ? shows controls
- [ ] Ctrl+Z undoes last placement
- [ ] Click block shows info

## Reference Games
- **Minecraft:** face-snap placement, instant, satisfying
- **Lego Builder's Journey:** snappy, visual clarity
- **Cities Skylines:** drag roads, grid overlay
- **The Sims 4:** room drawing, wall placement

## Definition of Done
A new player can open the game, understand the grid, place blocks rapidly, build vertically, undo mistakes, and know what floor they're on - with zero tutorial.

title: Implement chunk system for geometry batching
description:
# Chunk System for Geometry Batching

## Overview
Merge static block geometry into chunks to reduce draw calls.

### Chunk Size
- 8x8x8 cubes (48m Ã— 48m Ã— 28m world space)
- ~512 potential blocks per chunk
- Balance between rebuild cost and draw calls

### Chunk Manager
```gdscript
class_name ChunkManager extends Node3D

const CHUNK_SIZE: int = 8

var chunks: Dictionary = {}  # Vector3i -> Chunk

func get_chunk_coord(grid_pos: Vector3i) -> Vector3i:
    return Vector3i(
        floor(grid_pos.x / float(CHUNK_SIZE)),
        floor(grid_pos.y / float(CHUNK_SIZE)),
        floor(grid_pos.z / float(CHUNK_SIZE))
    )

func mark_chunk_dirty(chunk_coord: Vector3i)
func rebuild_chunk(chunk_coord: Vector3i)
```

### Per-Chunk Mesh Layers
1. **Opaque exterior** - Main geometry
2. **Transparent** - Glass panels
3. **Interior** - For cutaway rendering
4. **Dynamic** - Not merged (doors, elevators)

### Rebuild Strategy
- Mark dirty on block add/remove
- Rebuild during idle or end of frame
- Never rebuild more than N chunks per frame
- Priority: visible chunks first

### Frustum Culling
- Calculate AABB per chunk
- Cull entire chunks outside frustum
- Use VisibilityNotifier3D or manual check

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Chunks created/destroyed as needed
- [ ] Dirty chunks rebuild correctly
- [ ] Draw calls reduced significantly
- [ ] Frustum culling works
- [ ] Rebuild doesn't cause stutter

title: Render visible grid lines on terrain surface
description:
# Visible Grid Lines on Terrain

## Problem
The terrain is a flat gray plane with ZERO grid lines. Players have no idea where blocks will snap. This is the #1 building UX problem.

## Requirements

### Grid Shader
Create a shader that draws grid lines on the ground plane:

```gdshader
shader_type spatial;

uniform vec3 grid_color : source_color = vec3(0.3, 0.3, 0.3);
uniform float grid_spacing = 6.0;  // THE CUBE width
uniform float line_width = 0.05;
uniform float grid_opacity = 0.4;

void fragment() {
    vec3 world_pos = (INV_VIEW_MATRIX * vec4(VERTEX, 1.0)).xyz;
    
    // Grid lines at CUBE_WIDTH intervals
    vec2 grid = abs(fract(world_pos.xz / grid_spacing - 0.5) - 0.5) / fwidth(world_pos.xz / grid_spacing);
    float line = min(grid.x, grid.y);
    float grid_mask = 1.0 - min(line, 1.0);
    
    ALBEDO = mix(base_color, grid_color, grid_mask * grid_opacity);
}
```

### Visual Requirements
- Grid spacing: 6m (CUBE_WIDTH) on X and Z axes
- Lines visible at all zoom levels
- Lines fade at extreme distance (no shimmer/moire)
- Subtle but clear - not overwhelming
- Origin lines (X=0, Z=0) slightly brighter
- Grid extends to terrain bounds

### Optional: Height Grid
- When hovering at Y > 0, show vertical grid lines on ghost face
- Shows which floor level you're placing on

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Grid lines visible on terrain at 6m intervals
- [ ] Lines align exactly with block placement positions
- [ ] No visual artifacts at distance (anti-aliased)
- [ ] Visible in both free and ortho camera modes
- [ ] Origin axes slightly highlighted
- [ ] Grid doesn't overwhelm terrain texture

Evaluate SQLite vs JSON for game state persistence:

Current: JSON files in user://saves/

- Save file size (blocks count)
- Load time requirements  
- Query needs (find blocks by type, etc)
- Multiplayer considerations (future)

title: Implement cutaway visibility mode
description:
# Cutaway Visibility Mode

## Requirements
Remove all geometry above a horizontal cut plane.

### Controls
- Toggle: C key
- Adjust height: [ and ] keys
- Or: drag cut plane indicator

### Implementation: Shader-based Discard
```glsl
// Global shader parameter
uniform float cut_height;
uniform int visibility_mode;  // 0=normal, 1=cutaway, 2=xray, etc.

void fragment() {
    // Get world position
    vec3 world_pos = (INV_VIEW_MATRIX * vec4(VERTEX, 1.0)).xyz;
    
    // Cutaway mode
    if (visibility_mode == 1 && world_pos.y > cut_height) {
        discard;
    }
    
    // Normal rendering
    ALBEDO = albedo_color.rgb;
}
```

### Cut Plane Visualization
- Subtle plane indicator at cut height
- Edge glow on cut surfaces (optional)
- Floor label showing cut level

### VisibilityController
```gdscript
class_name VisibilityController extends Node

enum Mode { NORMAL, CUTAWAY, XRAY, ISOLATE, SECTION }

var mode: Mode = Mode.NORMAL
var cut_height: float = 100.0

signal mode_changed(new_mode)
signal cut_height_changed(height)

func set_mode(new_mode: Mode):
    mode = new_mode
    RenderingServer.global_shader_parameter_set("visibility_mode", mode)
    emit_signal("mode_changed", new_mode)

func set_cut_height(height: float):
    cut_height = height
    RenderingServer.global_shader_parameter_set("cut_height", height)
    emit_signal("cut_height_changed", height)
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] C toggles cutaway mode
- [ ] [ and ] adjust cut height
- [ ] Clean horizontal slice
- [ ] Interiors visible below cut
- [ ] Cut plane indicator visible
- [ ] Performance acceptable

title: Implement 3D raycast input handler
description:
# 3D Raycast Input Handler

## Requirements
Replace isometric math with 3D raycasting.

### Core Raycasting
```gdscript
func get_world_hit_at_cursor() -> Dictionary:
    var mouse_pos = get_viewport().get_mouse_position()
    var from = camera.project_ray_origin(mouse_pos)
    var dir = camera.project_ray_normal(mouse_pos)
    var to = from + dir * 2000.0
    
    var space = get_world_3d().direct_space_state
    var query = PhysicsRayQueryParameters3D.create(from, to)
    query.collision_mask = MASK_BLOCKS | MASK_TERRAIN
    
    var result = space.intersect_ray(query)
    if result:
        return {
            "hit": true,
            "position": result.position,
            "normal": result.normal,
            "collider": result.collider,
            "grid_pos": world_to_grid(result.position - result.normal * 0.1)
        }
    return {"hit": false}
```

### Collision Masks
- Bit 1: Terrain
- Bit 2: Blocks (opaque)
- Bit 3: Blocks (transparent)
- Bit 4: UI (for block under cursor detection)

### Face Detection
```gdscript
func normal_to_face(normal: Vector3) -> CubeFace:
    if normal.y > 0.5: return CubeFace.TOP
    if normal.y < -0.5: return CubeFace.BOTTOM
    if normal.z > 0.5: return CubeFace.NORTH
    if normal.z < -0.5: return CubeFace.SOUTH
    if normal.x > 0.5: return CubeFace.EAST
    return CubeFace.WEST
```

### Placement Position
```gdscript
func get_placement_position(hit: Dictionary) -> Vector3i:
    if not hit.hit: return Vector3i.ZERO
    var offset = Vector3i(
        int(round(hit.normal.x)),
        int(round(hit.normal.y)),
        int(round(hit.normal.z))
    )
    return hit.grid_pos + offset
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Raycast detects blocks and terrain
- [ ] Hit position accurate at all zoom levels
- [ ] Normal detection correct for all faces
- [ ] Placement position snaps correctly
- [ ] Works in both free and ortho camera modes

title: Implement X-ray visibility mode
description:
# X-Ray Visibility Mode

## Requirements
Make exterior walls transparent while keeping interiors solid.

### Controls
- Toggle: X key
- Transparency slider: 0-100%

### Implementation
Requires knowing which faces are "exterior" vs "interior":
- Exterior: faces adjacent to air/void
- Interior: faces adjacent to other blocks or inside

### Shader Approach
```glsl
uniform float xray_opacity;  // 0.0 to 1.0
uniform int visibility_mode;

// In fragment shader
if (visibility_mode == 2) {  // X-ray mode
    if (is_exterior_surface) {
        ALPHA = xray_opacity;
    }
}
```

### Exterior Detection Options

**Option 1: Per-face tagging**
- Tag each mesh face as exterior/interior at chunk build time
- Store in vertex colors or secondary UV

**Option 2: Depth peeling**
- Render back faces normally
- Render front faces with transparency
- More expensive but automatic

**Option 3: Fresnel-based**
- Faces perpendicular to view more transparent
- Not architecturally accurate but cheap

### Recommended: Per-face tagging
- At chunk mesh generation, mark exterior faces
- Store flag in vertex attribute
- Shader checks attribute for transparency

title: Implement placement validation with structural rules
description:
# Placement Validation System

## Validation Checks

### 1. Space Empty
```gdscript
func _check_space_empty(pos: Vector3i) -> ValidationResult:
    if grid.has_block_at(pos):
        return ValidationResult.invalid("Space is occupied")
    return ValidationResult.valid()
```

### 2. Structural Support
```gdscript
func _check_structural_support(pos: Vector3i, block_type: BlockType) -> ValidationResult:
    # Ground level always supported
    if pos.y == 0:
        return ValidationResult.valid()
    
    # Block below?
    if grid.has_block_at(pos + Vector3i(0, -1, 0)):
        return ValidationResult.valid()
    
    # Adjacent blocks for cantilever?
    for offset in [Vector3i(1,0,0), Vector3i(-1,0,0), Vector3i(0,0,1), Vector3i(0,0,-1)]:
        var adj = grid.get_block_at(pos + offset)
        if adj and adj.supports_cantilever:
            return ValidationResult.valid()
    
    return ValidationResult.invalid("No structural support")
```

### 3. Cantilever Limit
- Max 2 cubes horizontal without vertical support
- Check chain of unsupported blocks

### 4. Prerequisites
- Some blocks require adjacent infrastructure
- e.g., residential needs corridor access

### 5. Warnings (not blockers)
- "Will block natural light to floors below"
- "Corridor dead-ends here"
- "Far from utilities"

### Validation Result
```gdscript
class_name ValidationResult

var valid: bool
var reason: String
var warnings: Array[String]

static func valid() -> ValidationResult
static func invalid(reason: String) -> ValidationResult
static func warning(msg: String) -> ValidationResult
```

- [ ] Cantilever limit enforced
- [ ] Prerequisites checked
- [ ] Warnings returned but don't block

title: Highlight targeted face on hover
description:
# Highlight Targeted Face

## Problem
When hovering over a block, there's no indication of WHICH FACE the ghost will snap to. The 0.1m offset is invisible. Players don't know if they'll place on top, on the side, or in front.

## Requirements

### Face Highlight
When raycasting hits a block, highlight the hit face:

```gdscript
# Thin quad that covers the hit face
var face_highlight: MeshInstance3D  # Reusable

func update_face_highlight(hit_pos: Vector3, hit_normal: Vector3, grid_pos: Vector3i) -> void:
    face_highlight.visible = true
    
    # Position at the face center
    var block_center = grid_to_world_center(grid_pos)
    var face_offset = hit_normal * (get_face_dimension(hit_normal) / 2.0 + 0.01)
    face_highlight.global_position = block_center + face_offset
    
    # Rotate to face outward
    face_highlight.look_at(face_highlight.global_position + hit_normal)
    
    # Scale to face dimensions
    face_highlight.scale = get_face_scale(hit_normal)
```

### Visual
- Thin glowing quad on the hit face
- Color: white or light blue with 50% opacity
- Subtle pulse animation (breathe)
- Clearly shows: "your block will go HERE, on THIS side"

### Ghost + Face Together
- Face highlight shows WHERE you're clicking
- Ghost shows WHERE the new block will appear
- Together: instant spatial understanding

### Face Dimensions
```gdscript
func get_face_scale(normal: Vector3) -> Vector3:
    if abs(normal.y) > 0.5:  # Top/Bottom
        return Vector3(6.0, 1.0, 6.0)  # CUBE_WIDTH x CUBE_DEPTH
    elif abs(normal.x) > 0.5:  # East/West
        return Vector3(1.0, 3.5, 6.0)  # CUBE_HEIGHT x CUBE_DEPTH
    else:  # North/South
        return Vector3(6.0, 3.5, 1.0)  # CUBE_WIDTH x CUBE_HEIGHT
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Hovering over block highlights the face under cursor
- [ ] Highlight correctly sized for each face (top/side)
- [ ] Clearly communicates placement direction

# Adjacency Detection

## Overview
Blocks need to know their neighbors in 6 directions (Â±X, Â±Y, Â±Z) to calculate connectivity. This is the foundation for the connectivity flood-fill system.

## Requirements
1. Grid.get_neighbors(pos) returns 6 orthogonal neighbor positions
2. Grid.get_walkable_neighbors(pos) returns connected neighbors only
3. Consider block traversability (public vs private)

## The 6 Orthogonal Directions
```
+X = East  (1, 0, 0)
-X = West  (-1, 0, 0)
+Y = South (0, 1, 0)
-Y = North (0, -1, 0)
+Z = Up    (0, 0, 1)
-Z = Down  (0, 0, -1)
```

## Implementation
From `milestone-3-connectivity.md`:
```gdscript
func get_neighbors(pos: Vector3i) -> Array[Vector3i]:
    return [
        pos + Vector3i(1, 0, 0),   # East
        pos + Vector3i(-1, 0, 0),  # West
        pos + Vector3i(0, 1, 0),   # South
        pos + Vector3i(0, -1, 0),  # North
        pos + Vector3i(0, 0, 1),   # Up
        pos + Vector3i(0, 0, -1),  # Down
    ]
```

## Connectivity Rules
From `milestone-3-connectivity.md`:
1. **Horizontal** (X/Y): Two blocks connect if both exist and at least one is traversable
2. **Vertical** (Z): Only connects via stairs/elevator (see itx.5/6)
3. Private blocks are destinations, not through-routes

title: Implement connectivity flood-fill
description:
# Implement Connectivity Flood-Fill

## User Stories (from PRD)
- **US-015**: As a developer, I need a special entrance block and flood-fill connectivity check.

## Overview
Connectivity determines which blocks are reachable from the entrance. This is calculated using a breadth-first flood-fill algorithm starting from the entrance block.

## Requirements
1. `Grid.calculate_connectivity(entrance_pos: Vector3i)` method
2. BFS flood-fill from entrance position
3. Sets `block.connected = true` for reachable blocks
4. Sets `block.connected = false` for isolated blocks
5. Recalculates when blocks are added or removed

## Algorithm
```gdscript
func calculate_connectivity(entrance_pos: Vector3i) -> void:
    # Reset all blocks to disconnected
    for block in get_all_blocks():
        block.connected = false
    
    # BFS from entrance
    var queue: Array[Vector3i] = [entrance_pos]
    var visited: Dictionary = {entrance_pos: true}
    
    while not queue.is_empty():
        var pos = queue.pop_front()
        var block = get_block(pos)
        if block:
            block.connected = true
            
            # Add walkable neighbors to queue
            for neighbor_pos in get_walkable_neighbors(pos):
                if not visited.has(neighbor_pos):
                    visited[neighbor_pos] = true
                    queue.append(neighbor_pos)
```

## Traversability Rules
- **PUBLIC** blocks (corridor, stairs, elevator): Can route THROUGH
- **PRIVATE** blocks (residential, commercial): Can route TO but not through
- Horizontal connections: Both blocks exist, at least one is PUBLIC
- Vertical connections: Only via stairs/elevator (see itx.5/itx.6)

## Signals
- Connect to `block_added` and `block_removed` signals
- Recalculate connectivity on each change

## ðŸ“š Required Reading
- `documentation/architecture/milestones/milestone-3-connectivity.md`
- `documentation/game-design/core-concepts.md#public-vs-private-blocks`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `calculate_connectivity()` exists on Grid
- [ ] BFS visits all reachable blocks from entrance
- [ ] Blocks have `connected` property (bool)
- [ ] Connected blocks marked `connected = true`
- [ ] Isolated blocks marked `connected = false`
- [ ] Connectivity recalculates on block add/remove
close_reason: Implemented connectivity flood-fill with BFS algorithm, traversability rules, auto-recalculation, and full test coverage (33 unit + 15 integration tests)

## Requirements Questions (from PRD Section 6)

**PRD has sophisticated pathfinding beyond boolean connectivity:**

1. **Edge costs matter:** PRD defines traversal_speed and cost_modifier per block type. A Food Hall has cost 0.95 (preferred), a crowded corridor might have cost 1.5 (avoided).

2. **Travel time calculation:**
   ```
   edge_cost = (distance / traversal_speed) Ã— cost_modifier
   ```
   This affects resident happiness, not just "can I get there?"

3. **Pathfinding graph vs connectivity:**
   - Connectivity = "can I reach this block?" (boolean)
   - Pathfinding = "what's the best route?" (weighted)

**Questions:**
1. Is M3 just boolean connectivity (BFS flood-fill), or do we need weighted paths?
2. When do we calculate connectivity? On every block change? Lazy on query?
3. Should unconnected blocks be unbuildable, or just show warning?
4. What happens when entrance is removed? All blocks become unconnected?

## Proposed scope for M3:
- Boolean connectivity only (BFS from entrance)
- Recalculate on block add/remove (debounced)
- Store `connected: bool` per block
- Defer weighted pathfinding to M6 (when residents move)

## Critical insight:
Connectivity drives emergent gameplay: "Why won't anyone move into my apartments?" â†’ "Because they're not connected to the entrance!"

# Connectivity Flood-Fill

## User Stories (from PRD Section 6.9, 19)
- US-6.1: As a player, I want blocks to know if they're reachable from the entrance.
- US-19.2: As a developer, I want the pathfinding graph to be separate from the voxel grid for performance.

### Core Algorithm

   - Unreachable blocks get `connected = false`

2. **Traversability Rules:**
   - PUBLIC blocks (corridor, entrance, atrium, lobby): can route THROUGH
   - PRIVATE blocks (residential, office, restaurant): can route TO but not THROUGH
   - Two adjacent PRIVATE blocks do NOT connect through each other

```gdscript
# Each block stores:
var connected: bool = false

# Grid maintains:
var entrance_position: Vector3i  # seed for BFS
```

### Neighbor Connectivity
```
For BFS, a block connects to neighbor if:
- Neighbor exists (not empty)
- Current block is PUBLIC (can route through)
  OR current block is entrance (always traversable)
- Neighbor block is not VOID type
```

- Use Dictionary for visited set (Vector3i keys)
- Queue-based BFS, not recursive
- Store result on block.connected property
- Emit signal `connectivity_changed` when recalculated

- [ ] BFS correctly identifies all reachable blocks from entrance
- [ ] Private blocks can be destinations but not waypoints
- [ ] Recalculates on block add/remove with debounce
- [ ] Performance: <50ms for 1000 blocks

## Out of Scope (M6)
- Weighted pathfinding (edge costs, travel time)
- Multiple path options
- Congestion-aware routing

```gdscript
# Elevator shaft creates connections to ALL blocks in its vertical stack
func get_elevator_stack(pos: Vector3i) -> Array[Vector3i]:
    var stack = []
    var x = pos.x
```

# Save File Migration Script

## Problem
Coordinate system change:
- OLD: Vector3i(x, y, z) where z = floor level
- NEW: Vector3i(x, y, z) where y = vertical (floor), z = depth

## Migration Logic
```gdscript
func migrate_save_v1_to_v2(save_data: Dictionary) -> Dictionary:
    var migrated = save_data.duplicate(true)
    migrated["version"] = 2
    
    # Migrate block positions
    var new_blocks = []
    for block in save_data.blocks:
        var old_pos = block.position  # [x, y, z] old format
        var new_pos = [
            old_pos[0],   # x stays x
            old_pos[2],   # old z becomes new y (floor)
            old_pos[1]    # old y becomes new z (depth)
        ]
        block.position = new_pos
        new_blocks.append(block)
    
    migrated.blocks = new_blocks
    return migrated
```

## Save Format Versioning
```json
{
    "version": 2,
    "format": "arcology-3d",
    "blocks": [...],
    "game_state": {...}
}
```

## Migration Process
1. Load save file
2. Check version
3. If v1: run migration
4. If v2+: load directly

title: Implement LOD system for distant blocks
description:
# LOD System for Blocks

## LOD Levels

| LOD | Distance | Detail | Use |
|-----|----------|--------|-----|
| LOD0 | 0-50m | Full + interior | Close-up |
| LOD1 | 50-150m | Simplified exterior | Medium |
| LOD2 | 150-400m | Silhouette only | Far |
| LOD3 | 400m+ | Merged impostors | Very far |

## Implementation Options

### Option 1: Godot LOD (Recommended)
Use built-in LOD system with LODGroup or mesh_lod properties:
```gdscript
# In MeshInstance3D
mesh.surface_get_lod_count()
# Set LOD meshes on import
```

### Option 2: Manual Distance Check
```gdscript
func _process(_delta):
    var cam_pos = camera.global_position
    for block in visible_blocks:
        var dist = cam_pos.distance_to(block.global_position)
        var lod = _get_lod_for_distance(dist)
        if block.current_lod != lod:
            _switch_lod(block, lod)
```

### Option 3: Per-Chunk LOD
- Entire chunk switches LOD together
- Simpler, fewer transitions
- May have visible popping at boundaries

## LOD Mesh Requirements
- LOD0: Full detail, ~500-1000 triangles
- LOD1: Medium, ~100-200 triangles
- LOD2: Low, ~20-50 triangles
- LOD3: Billboard or merged cube

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] 4 LOD levels per block type
- [ ] Smooth transitions (no popping)
- [ ] Distance thresholds configurable
- [ ] Performance improves with LOD
- [ ] Interior only visible at LOD0

title: Epic: Audio & Spatial Sound Design â€” Ambient soundscape for a living 3D structure
description:
## Problem

Currently the only audio is a procedural placement click. City builders NEED ambient soundscapes to feel alive â€” the hum of activity, the quiet of residential floors, the bustle of commercial zones. In a 3D enclosed structure, audio is even more important because the player often CAN'T see what's happening (it's behind walls). Sound becomes a secondary information channel.

## What Needs Design

### Spatial Audio Architecture
- Camera position determines what the player hears
- Audio should change as camera moves through the structure:
  - Exterior: wind, city ambiance, bird sounds, distant traffic
  - Commercial floor: chatter, clinking, activity bustle
  - Residential floor: quiet, muffled sounds, occasional doors
  - Corridor: footsteps, echo, ventilation hum
  - Elevator shaft: mechanical sounds, whoosh
  - Underground: muffled, earthy, dripping
- Transition smoothly between zones as camera moves

### Sound Categories
1. **Ambient bed**: continuous background based on location (exterior/interior/underground)
2. **Activity sounds**: triggered by simulation events (residents moving, doors, cooking)
3. **System sounds**: HVAC hum, elevator motors, power generators, water pipes
4. **UI sounds**: placement, deletion, menu clicks, notifications, alerts
5. **Music**: adaptive soundtrack that responds to game state
6. **Environmental**: weather, time of day (crickets at night, birds at dawn)

### Occupancy-Based Audio
- Empty building: echo, silence, wind through corridors
- Populated building: life sounds proportional to density
- Overcrowded: cacophony, stress sounds
- Abandoned floor: eerie quiet, creaking
- This creates emotional feedback without any UI element

### Notification Audio
- Severity-coded alert sounds (see Notification epic)
- Not annoying at high frequency
- Optional spatial positioning (hear the problem's direction)

### Music System
- Adaptive/generative soundtrack
- Responds to: time of day, game speed, crisis state, AEI score, building scale
- Peaceful during building, tense during crises, triumphant at milestones
- Player can adjust or mute independently

### Performance Considerations
- Audio processing budget alongside rendering
- LOD for audio: full spatial audio near camera, simplified ambient for distant
- Max simultaneous audio sources
- Streaming vs. preloaded

## Open Questions
1. Should audio be a priority at all during Phase 0/1, or deferred until simulation exists?
2. Procedural audio (generate sounds) vs. recorded samples vs. hybrid?
3. How does audio interact with game speed? (Fast forward = pitched up? Compressed? Different track?)
4. Should there be a "listen" mode â€” pause game, close eyes, hear your arcology?
5. Accessibility: visual alternatives for all audio cues?
6. Budget for audio assets vs. procedural generation?

## Dependencies
- Agent simulation (milestone 7) â€” drives activity sounds
- Environment systems â€” drives system/ambient sounds
- Notification system (arcology-oag) â€” drives alert sounds
- Camera system â€” determines listener position
- Basically every system generates sound, so this is a cross-cutting concern

## Reference Games
- Cities Skylines: excellent spatial audio, changes with zoom level
- SimCity: iconic music, ambient city sounds
- Dwarf Fortress: minimal audio, cult following despite it
- Oxygen Not Included: great ambient audio that conveys system state
- Minecraft: spatial audio, biome-based ambient, iconic sounds

title: Epic: 3D Visibility & Interaction Design â€” How placement, selection, and management work inside enclosed structures
description:
## Problem

Visibility modes (cutaway, x-ray, isolate, section) are specced as independent features in the 3D refactor doc. But the HARD problem isn't implementing each mode â€” it's designing how they interact with every other system. This is the single most important UX challenge in the game.

The player is building, inspecting, and managing a structure they cannot see all of at once. Every interaction must be designed with "but the thing I want to click is behind 4 walls" in mind.

## What Needs Design

### Visibility Mode Ã— Placement Interaction
- I'm in cutaway mode at floor 5. I click to place a block. Does it:
  (a) Place at floor 5 (the cut plane)?
  (b) Place wherever the ray hits below the cut plane?
  (c) Place on the cut plane surface as if it were solid ground?
- Ghost preview during cutaway â€” does the ghost render above the cut plane? (It should, so you can see what you're building)
- I'm in x-ray mode and click a transparent exterior wall â€” do I select the wall, or the block behind it?
- Floor isolate + placement: can I only place on the isolated floor, or can I still build up/down?

### Visibility Mode Ã— Selection Interaction
- Click to select a block that's behind walls â€” does the game auto-activate cutaway/x-ray?
- In x-ray mode, clicking should prioritize interior blocks over transparent exteriors
- Box selection in 3D â€” does the selection box respect the current visibility mode? (Only select visible blocks? Or all blocks in the 3D volume?)
- How do you select a block that's completely enclosed? (No exposed face to click)

### Visibility Mode Transitions
- Switching between modes should be seamless, not jarring
- Camera position should be preserved across mode switches
- What's the default mode? (Normal â†’ cutaway is probably the most common transition)
- Should modes be stackable? (Cutaway + x-ray simultaneously?)
- Quick-toggle: press and hold C for temporary cutaway, release to return?

### The "Enclosed Block" Problem
- Player builds a solid 5x5x5 cube. The center block (2,2,2) is completely enclosed â€” no face is visible in any mode.
- How do you: select it? Delete it? Inspect it? Replace it?
- Options: section mode (vertical slice), x-ray mode (see through), floor isolate (horizontal slice), or "peel" tool (strip layers)
- This WILL happen â€” players will enclose blocks accidentally and intentionally

### Ghost Preview Depth Cues
- When placing blocks deep inside a structure, how does the player judge depth?
- Ghost preview needs strong depth cues: outline, shadow, depth-based transparency
- Face labels on ghost (currently showing face + rotation) help â€” but are they enough?
- Consider: "depth indicator" showing how far the ghost is from the camera in grid units

### Notification â†’ Visibility Mode Chain
- Player gets notification: "Block on floor 12 has no light"
- Click notification â†’ camera flies to floor 12 â†’ cutaway activates at floor 13 â†’ problem block highlights
- This chain (notification â†’ camera move â†’ visibility mode â†’ highlight) needs to feel automatic and smooth
- What if the problem is underground? Camera needs to transition smoothly to below-grade views

### Information at Different Visibility Levels
- Normal mode: exterior only, show aggregate health indicators on surface
- Cutaway: show floor interior, individual block status
- X-ray: show structure + activity simultaneously, block types as colored volumes
- Isolate: detailed single-floor view, room-level information
- Section: architectural cross-section, useful for understanding vertical systems (elevator shafts, light pipes)

## Open Questions
1. Should there be a dedicated "inspection mode" vs "build mode"? (The Sims: Live mode vs Build mode)
2. Can visibility modes be assigned per-region? ("Always show the lobby in cutaway")
3. Should cutaway height track the camera tilt? (Tilt down â†’ cut plane lowers automatically)
4. How do overlays (light, noise, safety heat maps) render in each visibility mode?
5. Is there a "focus mode" â€” click a block, and everything else dims/fades except that block and its immediate context?
6. Should the scroll wheel adjust cut-plane height when in cutaway mode, instead of zoom?
7. How do multi-cell blocks render when the cut plane bisects them? (Cut through a 3x2 wall â€” show the cross-section?)

## Dependencies
- Visibility modes implementation (arcology-5e2.9, arcology-9qx)
- Selection system (arcology-d4g)
- Notification system (not yet designed)
- Ghost preview system (exists in Phase 0, needs extension)
- Overlay system (milestone 10)
- Wayfinding epic (arcology-s6b) â€” heavy overlap on navigation-driven visibility

## Why This Is the Hardest Problem
In a 2D game, you can see everything. The design challenge is information density.
In a 3D game with OPEN structures (Cities Skylines), you can see most things. The challenge is camera control.
In a 3D game with ENCLOSED structures (Arcology), you can see almost NOTHING without tools. The challenge is making the invisible visible without overwhelming the player.

Every feature in the game â€” placement, management, simulation inspection â€” flows through this problem. Get it right and the game is magical. Get it wrong and it's unplayable.

title: Epic: Player Wayfinding & Navigation â€” Finding things inside a 3D enclosed structure
description:
## Problem

In Cities Skylines, you look DOWN at a flat plane â€” everything is visible. In Arcology, you're building a structure players look INTO. Once the arcology hits 10+ floors with enclosed corridors and stacked residential blocks, the player's #1 question becomes: "Where is the thing I'm looking for?"

This is a design problem unique to 3D enclosed structures. Visibility modes (cutaway, x-ray) help you SEE, but wayfinding helps you FIND. No docs currently address this.

## What Needs Design

### The Core Problem
A player built a 30-floor arcology with 5,000 blocks. They get a notification: "Restaurant on floor 12 has no customers." How do they:
1. Find that restaurant?
2. Navigate the camera to it?
3. Understand WHY it has no customers (is it disconnected? no corridor access? too far from residential?)
4. Return to what they were doing before?

### Wayfinding Tools to Consider

**Floor Index / Directory**
- Sidebar showing floor-by-floor breakdown
- Click a floor â†’ camera jumps to floor-isolate view
- Shows block type counts per floor (12 residential, 3 commercial, 1 corridor...)
- Collapsible tree: Floor 12 â†’ Restaurant "Block #847" â†’ click to focus

**Search / Find**
- Search box: type "restaurant" â†’ highlights all restaurants in the structure
- Filter by: block type, status (occupied/vacant), problems (no access, no light)
- Results show as a list AND as highlighted blocks in the 3D view
- Click result â†’ camera flies to that block

**Minimap / Cross-Section**
- Small window showing a 2D cross-section of the arcology at current camera height
- Or: a small top-down floor plan of the current floor
- Player's camera position shown as indicator
- Click minimap to move camera

**Bookmarks / Pins**
- Player pins locations: "Main lobby", "Problem area", "Expansion zone"
- Hotkey to cycle between bookmarks
- Persistent across sessions (saved with game)
- Camera bookmark tickets exist (arcology-5xn) but this is broader â€” location + context, not just camera angle

**Breadcrumb Trail / Camera History**
- Camera history exists (Backspace in orbital_camera.gd) â€” this is good
- Extend to: "go back to where I was before I clicked that notification"
- Stack-based: notification pulls camera â†’ player investigates â†’ press Back â†’ return to previous position

**Notification-Driven Navigation**
- When a problem occurs, notification appears in feed
- Click notification â†’ camera flies to the problem location, cutaway mode activates if needed
- "Next problem" / "Previous problem" cycling
- Problem markers visible in 3D space (floating icons above problem blocks)

**Overlay-Based Discovery**
- "Show me all blocks with light < 50%" â†’ heat map overlay activates, camera enters overview mode
- "Show me disconnected blocks" â†’ disconnected blocks pulse red
- "Show me where residents are unhappy" â†’ satisfaction heat map
- These exist conceptually in milestone 10 (overlays) but the NAVIGATION aspect â€” "overlay as wayfinding tool" â€” isn't designed

### Information Density at Different Scales
- Zoomed in (1-5 blocks): show block details, resident names, real-time activity
- Mid zoom (floor level): show block types as colored cubes, aggregate stats
- Zoomed out (whole arcology): show system health as heat map, floor labels, problem indicators
- The information shown should change with zoom level â€” too much detail at overview scale is noise

## Open Questions
1. What's the primary wayfinding metaphor â€” floor plans (architectural), search (database), or spatial (minimap)?
2. Should the game have a "schematic view" â€” an abstract 2D floor plan mode for management?
3. How do wayfinding tools interact with visibility modes? (e.g., search highlights a block that's behind walls â€” auto-activate cutaway?)
4. Should blocks have player-assignable names/labels? ("My favorite restaurant", "Problem zone")
5. Is a minimap worth the screen real estate, or is the View Cube enough?
6. How do notifications route attention without being annoying? (Dwarf Fortress problem)
7. At what arcology size does wayfinding become critical? (probably 500+ blocks / 10+ floors)

## Dependencies
- Visibility modes (cutaway/x-ray) must work first â€” wayfinding tools will activate them automatically
- Notification system (not yet designed) feeds into navigation
- Overlay system (milestone 10) overlaps significantly
- Camera bookmark system (arcology-5xn) is a small piece of this
- Search/filter requires block metadata to be queryable

## Reference Games
- Dwarf Fortress: z-level navigation, designation overlays, announcements â†’ zoom-to-location
- RimWorld: architect categories, zone overlays, alert system
- SimTower: floor selector sidebar, elevator visualization
- The Sims: room-by-room camera, live mode vs build mode
- Oxygen Not Included: overlay system as primary navigation tool

# Rapid-Fire Block Placement

## Problem
Currently you click once per block. Building a wall or floor means click-click-click-click. In Minecraft you hold the button and sweep. We need that.

## Requirements

### Hold-to-Place
```gdscript
var _placing: bool = false
var _last_placed_pos: Vector3i = Vector3i(-999, -999, -999)
var _place_cooldown: float = 0.0
const PLACE_INTERVAL: float = 0.1  # 100ms between placements

func _unhandled_input(event: InputEvent) -> void:
    if event is InputEventMouseButton:
        if event.button_index == MOUSE_BUTTON_LEFT:
            _placing = event.pressed
            if event.pressed:
                _try_place()  # Immediate on click

func _process(delta: float) -> void:
    update_ghost()
    
    if _placing:
        _place_cooldown -= delta
        if _place_cooldown <= 0:
            _try_place()
            _place_cooldown = PLACE_INTERVAL

    var pos = get_placement_position()
```

- Moving cursor while held: places at each new grid cell
- Audio: rapid "click-click-click" at placement rate

- Track last placed position
- Don't re-place at same grid cell while held
- Only place when cursor moves to new cell

title: Epic: Notification & Attention Routing â€” Surfacing problems inside an enclosed 3D structure
description:
## Problem

When a crisis happens deep inside a 50-floor structure â€” a power failure on floor 23, a fight in the food hall, a backed-up elevator â€” how does the player know? You can't flash a tile red when it's behind 4 walls on a floor the player isn't looking at.

In 2D city builders, problems are visually obvious (burning building, traffic jam visible from above). In a 3D enclosed structure, problems are invisible by default. The notification system IS the management interface.

## What Needs Design

### Notification Types & Severity
- **Critical** (immediate attention): structural failure, fire, riot, mass exodus
- **Warning** (check when convenient): overcrowding, light deprivation, rising crime
- **Info** (FYI): new resident moved in, business opened, milestone reached
- **Opportunity** (positive): "Floor 15 residents are especially happy â€” what's working there?"

### Notification Feed
- Scrolling feed (like Dwarf Fortress announcements or Cities Skylines chirper)
- Filterable by type, severity, floor, system
- Grouped: "12 residents on floor 8 complain about noise" (not 12 separate notifications)
- Aging: old notifications fade, resolved ones auto-dismiss
- Rate limiting: prevent notification spam during cascading failures

### Click-to-Navigate
- Click any notification â†’ camera flies to the relevant location
- Automatic visibility mode activation:
  - Problem on floor 12 â†’ cutaway at floor 13
  - Problem underground â†’ camera descends, ground becomes transparent
  - Transit issue â†’ highlight the affected corridor path
- Highlight pulse on the problem block/area
- "Back" button to return to previous camera position after investigating

### Persistent Problem Markers
- Unresolved problems get 3D markers floating above the problem location
- Visible through walls (like quest markers in RPGs, but subtle)
- Color-coded by severity
- Dismissable individually or by type
- Toggle visibility of markers (might be distracting during building)

### Alert Sounds
- Severity-appropriate audio cues
- Not annoying at high frequency (Dwarf Fortress problem: constant alerts = player mutes them)
- Spatial audio option: hear problems that are near the camera louder than distant ones?

### System Health Dashboard
- Aggregate view: "Power: 78%, Water: 92%, Transit: 45% (WARNING), Safety: 88%"
- Click a system â†’ overlay activates showing that system's status across the arcology
- Trend indicators: "Transit capacity declining over last 5 minutes"
- This is the large-scale management interface (see Scale Transition epic)

### Notification Ã— Simulation Interaction
- Which simulation events generate notifications?
- Threshold-based: "notify when any floor drops below 50% light"
- Player-configurable thresholds? ("I don't care about noise complaints under 60dB")
- Cooldown per issue: don't re-notify about the same problem every tick

## Open Questions
1. How prominent should notifications be? (Subtle feed vs. modal popups for critical?)
2. Should the player be able to set up "watches" on specific blocks/floors/systems?
3. Do notifications pause the game? (Critical ones might warrant a pause + camera move)
4. Is there an advisor character who contextualizes notifications? ("Your east wing is losing residents because elevator wait times exceed 3 minutes")
5. How do notifications work in sandbox mode? (No simulation = no problems to report)
6. Should there be a "morning report" / summary when unpausing after being away?
7. Notification history â€” can the player review past notifications like a log?

## Dependencies
- Visibility mode interaction (arcology-pre) â€” notifications trigger visibility changes
- Wayfinding (arcology-s6b) â€” notifications are a wayfinding mechanism
- Camera system â€” needs "fly to location" animation support
- Agent simulation (milestone 7) â€” generates resident-related notifications
- Environment systems (milestones 4-5) â€” generate system health notifications
- Economy system (arcology-gi6) â€” generates financial notifications

title: Epic: Save/Load & Persistence â€” Data model serialization, save format, autosave
description:
## Problem

There are zero tickets for persistence anywhere in the backlog. Data model decisions being made NOW (how blocks, grid state, scenario config, cell occupancy are stored) directly affect save format. Retrofitting serialization onto a data model designed without it is painful and bug-prone.

Even Phase 0 benefits from "save this build, reload it later" â€” without it, every test session starts from scratch.

## What Needs Design

### Data Model Serialization
- How are placed blocks serialized? (block_id, definition_id, origin Vector3i, rotation, occupied_cells)
- How is grid state stored? (cell_occupancy dictionary, ground strata state, excavation state)
- How is scenario config persisted? (50+ parameters from ScenarioConfig)
- What's the format? (JSON? Godot Resource? Binary? Compressed?)
- How do multi-cell blocks serialize? (store origin + definition, or every cell?)

### Save File Format
- Version header for migration compatibility
- What metadata goes in the save? (timestamp, playtime, scenario name, block count, screenshot thumbnail?)
- File size targets for large arcologies (50k+ blocks)
- Compression strategy

### Save/Load UX
- Manual save slots vs. named saves
- Autosave interval and slot rotation
- Quick-save / quick-load keybinds
- Save file browser with thumbnails
- "Are you sure?" confirmation on overwrite

### Migration Strategy
- How do save files survive game updates?
- Version field in save format from day one
- Migration functions per version bump
- What breaks saves vs. what's backward-compatible?

### Edge Cases
- Saving during simulation tick â€” snapshot consistency
- Very large saves (200k blocks) â€” async save to avoid frame stutter
- Corrupt save recovery
- Cloud save considerations (future)

## Open Questions
1. Should Phase 0 sandbox have save/load, or wait for the "real" game scene?
2. JSON (human-readable, debuggable) vs binary (compact, fast) vs Godot .tres/.res?
3. Should save files include undo history?
4. How does save format interact with scenario config â€” is the scenario embedded or referenced?
5. Should there be an export format for sharing builds (stripped-down, no simulation state)?

## Dependencies
- Affects every system that stores state: grid, blocks, agents, economy, environment
- Should be designed before Milestone 5 (Economy) adds mutable game state beyond blocks
- ScenarioConfig (arcology-3kj) should be designed with serialization in mind

## Reference

- Current block data: src/phase0/block_definition.gd, placed_block.gd
- Scenario config: src/phase0/scenario_config.gd

# Grid Data Structure

## Overview
The Grid is the core data structure storing all blocks in a sparse 3D dictionary. It provides coordinate conversion between grid space (Vector3i) and screen space (Vector2) for isometric rendering.

## Requirements
1. Sparse 3D dictionary storing Block references by Vector3i position
2. Constants: TILE_WIDTH=64, TILE_HEIGHT=32, FLOOR_HEIGHT=24
3. Methods:
   - set_block(pos: Vector3i, block: Block) -> void
   - get_block(pos: Vector3i) -> Block or null
   - remove_block(pos: Vector3i) -> void
   - has_block(pos: Vector3i) -> bool
   - get_all_blocks() -> Array[Block]
4. Coordinate conversion:
   - grid_to_screen(pos: Vector3i) -> Vector2
   - screen_to_grid(screen_pos: Vector2, z_level: int) -> Vector3i
5. Signals:
   - block_added(pos: Vector3i, block: Block)
   - block_removed(pos: Vector3i)

## Isometric Math
From `milestone-1-grid-blocks.md`:
```gdscript
func grid_to_screen(pos: Vector3i) -> Vector2:
    var x = (pos.x - pos.y) * (TILE_WIDTH / 2)
    var y = (pos.x + pos.y) * (TILE_HEIGHT / 2) - pos.z * FLOOR_HEIGHT
    return Vector2(x, y)
```

## ðŸ“š Required Reading
- `documentation/architecture/milestones/milestone-1-grid-blocks.md` - Grid code samples
- `documentation/quick-reference/isometric-math.md` - Full conversion formulas

- [ ] screen_to_grid inverts correctly for given Z level

title: Setup isometric rendering with Y-sort
description:
# Setup Isometric Rendering with Y-Sort

## Overview
Blocks must render at correct isometric screen positions with proper depth sorting. Higher grid Y values render behind (further from camera), and higher Z values (floors) render above.

## Requirements
1. Block container node with y_sort_enabled = true
2. Sprite positioning uses Grid.grid_to_screen()
3. Z-ordering rules:
   - Higher grid Y = renders behind (further from camera)
   - Higher grid Z = renders above (stacked floors)
   - Formula: sprite.z_index = pos.x + pos.y + pos.z * 100
4. When blocks added/removed, sprites update positions

## Implementation
```gdscript
# In BlockRenderer or similar
func _update_sprite_position(block: Block, sprite: Sprite2D) -> void:
    sprite.position = Grid.grid_to_screen(block.grid_position)
    sprite.z_index = _calculate_z_index(block.grid_position)

func _calculate_z_index(pos: Vector3i) -> int:
    return pos.x + pos.y + pos.z * 100
```

- `documentation/architecture/milestones/milestone-1-grid-blocks.md` - Rendering requirements
- `documentation/quick-reference/isometric-math.md` - Coordinate conversions

title: Epic: Scale Transition & Progressive Complexity â€” How gameplay evolves from 100 blocks to 50,000
description:
## Problem

Gameplay at 100 blocks and gameplay at 50,000 blocks are fundamentally different experiences. At small scale, you're an architect placing individual blocks. At large scale, you're a city manager handling systems, crises, and populations. The game needs to evolve as the arcology grows.

Cities Skylines solves this with milestone unlocks (population thresholds gate new building types and tools). SimCity uses advisors and progressive complexity. Dwarf Fortress... doesn't solve it, and that's partly why it's famously overwhelming.

Arcology's unique challenge: the structure is VERTICAL and ENCLOSED, so scale problems compound â€” more floors = harder to see, harder to navigate, harder to manage.

## What Needs Design

### The Scale Spectrum

**Tiny (1-50 blocks, <100 residents)**
- Player mindset: architect, experimenting
- Placing individual blocks, learning mechanics
- No systems pressure â€” survival needs trivially met
- Camera: close zoom, inspecting individual blocks
- Tools needed: basic palette, placement, removal

**Small (50-500 blocks, 100-1,000 residents)**
- Player mindset: builder, creating a vision
- First corridors, first elevator, first commercial block
- Light and air start mattering (interior blocks get dark)
- First resident complaints appear
- Tools needed: visibility modes (cutaway becomes essential), basic overlays

**Medium (500-5,000 blocks, 1,000-10,000 residents)**
- Player mindset: planner, balancing systems
- Economy matters â€” rent income vs. infrastructure cost
- Transit congestion (corridors too narrow, elevator wait times)
- Social dynamics emerge (neighborhoods, status stratification)
- Tools needed: area fill, floor repeat, search/filter, notification system
- Performance: chunk system becomes necessary

**Large (5,000-50,000 blocks, 10,000-100,000 residents)**
- Player mindset: mayor, managing crises
- Individual blocks are noise â€” thinking in floors/zones/districts
- Entropy is a real threat (maintenance costs, decay)
- Political dynamics (NIMBYism, faction conflicts)
- Tools needed: blueprints, zoning brush, district management, automation
- Performance: LOD system essential, simulation LOD for distant agents

**Mega (50,000+ blocks, 100,000+ residents)**
- Player mindset: systems thinker, cultivating emergence
- Most management is automated or delegated
- Watching for emergent behavior, nudging systems
- Eudaimonia score is the primary metric
- Victory conditions become relevant
- Tools needed: statistical dashboards, policy levers, macro-level overlays

### Progressive Unlocks
- What unlocks at each scale tier?
- New block types? New tools? New overlays? New management UI?
- Should unlocks be gated by population, block count, height, AEI score, or time?
- Is it a strict gate ("you need 1000 residents to unlock X") or soft ("X becomes available when useful")?

### Tool Evolution
- At 50 blocks: place individual blocks, it's fun
- At 500 blocks: individual placement is tedious, need area fill
- At 5000 blocks: area fill is tedious, need floor repeat/blueprints
- At 50000 blocks: blueprints are tedious, need zoning/auto-generation
- The toolset should grow WITH the arcology

### Management Abstraction Layers
- At small scale: manage individual blocks (this block needs light)
- At medium scale: manage floors (floor 12 needs more corridors)
- At large scale: manage zones/districts (the east wing has poor connectivity)
- At mega scale: manage systems (transit system is at 80% capacity)
- The UI needs to present information at the right abstraction level

### The Tedium Cliff
- Every city builder has a point where the player stops having fun building and starts grinding
- In Cities Skylines: happens around 50k population when you're just filling zones
- In Arcology: will happen when the player needs to build floor 51 and it's identical to floor 50
- Mitigation: repeat tools, blueprints, auto-fill, template floors
- Question: should the game auto-build some things? (Auto-extend corridors, auto-place utilities?)

### Difficulty Curves
- Sandbox mode: no pressure, build at your own pace
- Scenario mode: specific goals at specific scales
- The learning curve should match the scale curve â€” new mechanics introduced as they become relevant, not all at once

## Open Questions
1. What are the concrete tier thresholds? (Block count? Population? Height? AEI?)
2. Should tiers be visible to the player? ("Your arcology is now MEDIUM tier!")
3. Is there an explicit tutorial/advisor system, or do tools just appear when relevant?
4. How do you handle players who want to jump straight to mega-scale? (Creative mode?)
5. Should there be auto-build or delegation systems? (Hire an AI architect NPC?)
6. How does the AEI (victory metric) relate to scale? Is a small, happy arcology a valid win?
7. Does entropy scale with size? (Bigger = harder to maintain, creating natural growth limits?)

## Dependencies
- Multi-block operations (arcology-3s2) â€” needed for medium scale+
- Wayfinding (arcology-s6b) â€” needed for medium scale+
- Economy system (arcology-gi6) â€” drives medium scale tension
- Notification system â€” drives large scale management
- Overlay system (milestone 10) â€” drives all management scales
- Agent simulation (milestone 7) â€” drives population dynamics

## Reference Games
- Cities Skylines: milestone unlocks, progressive tool access, advisor tips
- Factorio: research tree gates tools, scale drives complexity
- Dwarf Fortress: no progression gates, steep cliff, cult following but niche
- SimTower: star rating system (1-5 stars) gates building types
- Banished: population pressure drives expansion naturally

# Floor Visibility System

## Overview
Controls block visibility based on floor level. Current floor is fully visible, floors below fade with depth, and floors above are hidden. This creates a "cutaway" view into the structure.

## Requirements
1. Current floor: 100% opacity (fully visible)
2. Floor below (Z-1): 70% opacity
3. Two floors below (Z-2): 40% opacity
4. Floors above current: hidden (0% opacity)
5. Updates when current_floor changes

## Implementation
From `milestone-2-floor-navigation.md`:
```gdscript
func update_visibility() -> void:
    for pos in Grid.blocks:
        var block = Grid.get_block(pos)
        if pos.z > current_floor:
            # Above current floor - hide
            block.sprite.visible = false
        elif pos.z == current_floor:
            # Current floor - full opacity
            block.sprite.visible = true
            block.sprite.modulate.a = 1.0
        elif pos.z >= current_floor - floors_below_visible:
            # Below but within visible range - fade
            block.sprite.visible = true
            var depth = current_floor - pos.z
            block.sprite.modulate.a = 1.0 - (depth * 0.3)
        else:
            # Too far below - hide
            block.sprite.visible = false
```

## Connect to GameState
- Listen to GameState.floor_changed signal
- Call update_visibility() on change

description:
# Bug: Floating build category buttons appearing in game viewport

## Description
In the visual test screenshot, there are floating build category buttons (Res, Com, Ind, Tra, Grn, Civ, Inf) appearing in the middle of the game viewport area, separate from the proper bottom bar.

## Expected
Build category buttons should only appear in the HUD bottom bar, not floating in the game area.

## Observed
Screenshot shows duplicate category buttons floating around coordinates (700, 550) in the game viewport.

## Possible Causes
1. BuildToolbar flyout panel is positioned incorrectly
2. A second instance of build UI being created
3. Legacy BlockPicker (hidden but maybe not fully disabled)
4. Flyout not being properly hidden/positioned

## To Reproduce
1. Run visual test: `./scripts/qa/visual.sh`
2. View screenshot at `test_output/screenshot.png`
3. Note floating category buttons in game area

## Files to Check
- src/ui/build_toolbar.gd (flyout positioning)
- src/ui/block_picker.gd (should be hidden)
- src/core/main.gd (_setup_build_toolbar)
